(A copy of this letter was circul he interested Departments on 15th July, 1936, and dr mail to the Government of India, Bushire and Bahrein on the 12th September matter careful consideration and quite sympathised with the feelings of H.M.G. as expressed in the earlier part of the letter. Thej* were anxious to give some assurances to H.M.G., hut they did not feel that they were in a position to give the specific assurances requested. They left it to Mr. Ballantyne to work out something which would he satisfactory to H. M. G. and which would also he possible for them to subscribe. He explained that there were certain objections to the specific assurances suggested. In the first place the Standard Oil Company of California and the Texas Company, the present parent companies, are public companies and no control can be exercised over dealings in tneir shares. Any assurance by the Board of the Bahrein Petroleum Company could not prevent changes in the control of the parent companies and therefore an assurance of the Icmd suggested would not be of very much use., secondly, the Board of the B.P.C. would not in any case ieel able to give an unqualified assurance of the kind suggested, principally because, while the 'present Articles Ox Absociaoion of the Company give the Board complete control/ Mr. Ballantyne said that the Companyt control over movements of shares, the articles might 'be changed in such a way as to remove that power. The Board did not feel they could safely give an assurance that the Articles of Association would neve r he altered in this respect - though of course there is no intention whatever of altering them. Thirdly, and this I think was Mr. Ballantyne's main point, an assurance of the kind suggested could easily be got round by the Company if they wanted to do so. For instance, to take the case of the recent mei ^er, tue u., instead oi giving half the shares to the Texas Company, might have made an agreement with then; undertaking to let them have the whole produce of the Bahrein field, or something of that kind. This would really have had the same effect from the point of view of H.M.G., i.e. it would have brought another company very much into the Bahrein picture. If the company had been a Japanese, German or Italian company, H.M.G. might have objected very much to the arrangement, but under the assurances at present proposed they would not have had any right to do so. It was not very easy to follow Mr.Ballantyne's arguments, particularly the legal ones, but his real point io Perfectly clear, viz. that any specific assurances of thu Kind suggested, even if the Company felt that they could safely subscribe to them, would not be really eixecti/e from iI.ivl.Cx. s point of view. Ballantyne saying that H.M.G. regretted the Company were/1 were unable to do this, but that the Company should recognise that H.M.G., 'both on historical and strategic grounds and in view of their special treaty relations with ;,ie Arab Rulers, have special interests in the Persian Gulf area and that H.M.G. hope that in dealing with any matters connected with the control of the Company or of its policy and operations the Company would bear in mind these special interests and take care to avoid any action which might in any way prejudice them. The point of this would be that the Company (who would, under this arrangement, acknowledge the receipt of our letter) would have permanently before them a general obligation to respect H.M.G.'s special interests. This would involve consulting H.M.G. in advance if there was any proposal the effect of which might in any way infringe on these rights (e.g. if there were some suggestion of a combination with an Italian firm or the like). If the Company at some future time actually did something which prejudiced H.M.G.'s interests it would be open to H.M.G. to use their political predominance in the Gulf to make the Company's position thoroughly uncomfortable and the Company would not be able to complain in the light of the present correspondence. Petroleum Department (Mi ne s De pa rt me nt) Dean Stanley St. Millbank, London,S.W. 1 No.P.D.21/4. 12th June,1937 Iv5j dear Glaus on, With reference to your letter of 18th May on the subject of the preferential rates of duty in Australia and New Zealand for Bahrein oils, while I think it is unlikely that either of these two countries would accede to the request of the Bahrein Petroleum Company, I do not think we should allow the matter to be put to the test. As you know, there is no preference in the United Kingdom for Empire oils. Trinidad have applied for a preference on motor spirit on a number of occasions in recent years, but have been turned down. Empire production (apart from Bahrein) is very small and is confined to Trinidad, Sarawak and Brunei, Burmah and India. Burmah production is absorbed in India, Trinidad oil enjoys a preference in some of the West Indian Islands, but that is largely a local arrangement. It also enjoys a preference in Sierra Leone, but the quantity of oil involved is almost negligible. The only cases in which we have endeavoured to obtain preference have been in respect of lubricating oils manufactured in this country. This is a rather specialised trade faced with stiff American competition, the American sources of supply being very much nearer to both the West Indies and tne Australasian markets. Over a period of years we have managed to secure a few improvements in the qualifying conditions in both places. ■B-Uson Esq f .ia Office' Whitehall,s.W.1. Any/'O 2. Any general extension of preference to motor spirit, fuel oil, etc., would not in practice benefit Empire producers. On the other hand, the grant of a preference to Bahrein oil would, in certain countriesj notahly Australia, enable the Bahrein Company to compete on favourable terms with existing British interests marketing oil not of empire origin. This question arose in July last, when the marketing arrangements with the Texas Company were under discussion. On that occasion I mentioned that there were certain advantages from the point of view of our big oil groups in a Company like the Texas handling the oil, since it will then flow into the channels where they normally trade, and thus there would be a minimum of disturbance of markets, which is all to the good from the point of view of British oil interests. (See my letter of 3rd July, 1936, I.O.ref.P.Z,4298/36.) But if the Bahrein-Texas Company is going to get a preference in certain markets, it cannot but prejudice the interests of the Anglo- Iranian and Shell Companies. To take the case of Australia;, I enclose a statement showing the imports of petroleum products in the year 1954/5, from which you will see that the bulk of the imports are obtained from Dutch East Indies and Persia, the Shell Group and the Anglo-Iranian being the principal companies concerned. The latter Company operate through the Commonwealth Oil Refineries,Limited, one half of whose capital is held by the Commonwealth Government. I suggest, therefore, that it should be pointed out to Ballantyne in general terms that the quantity of oil produced in the Empire is small, and that the seeking or granting of preferences on oil products generally has not been the policy of H.M,Government. physicalDescription.extent: The documents in the volume are arranged in chronological order. There is an index at the end of the volume, (folios 246-271). The index is arranged chronologically and refers to documents within the volume; it gives brief description of the correspondence with a reference number in red crayon or ink, which refers back to that correspondence in the volume.

The foliation starts at the titlepage and terminates at the 4th sheet from the back of the volume; these numbers are written in pencil and can be found in the top right corner, mostly uncircled. The numbering starts with 1A and 1B; then 2-16; 17A and 17B; 18A and 18B; 19A and 19B; 20, 21; 22A and 22B; 23-33; 34 is skipped; 35-42; 43A and 43B; 44-46; 47A and 47B; 48-141; 142A and 142B; 143-196; 197A and 197B; 198-234; 235A and 235B and then carries on until 271, which is the last number given to the last page of writing.

mods.abstract: The volume contains correspondence and telegrams between the Political Agent in Bahrain, the Political Resident in Bushire, the Financial Adviser to the Government in Bahrain, Charles Dalrymple Belgrave, and representatives of the Bahrain Petroleum Company Limited (BAPCO) on reservation of land and infrastructures to be built on Sitra Island.The volume contains technical drawings and maps by BAPCO:'Marine and Submarine facilities' (f. 22B);'Proposed reservation for Refinery, water wells & lines to Sitra.' (3 copies on ff. 47B, 142A and 182);'Permanent Camp Reservation' (f. 70);'A reservation for marine and sub-marine facilities at Zellaq' (f. 129);'Reservation for the Outfall Sewer right-of-way East of the Easterly Concession Boundary Bahrein Is' (f. 134);'Shafaba Garden - N.E. of Parcel #4, Refinery Reservations' (f. 142B);'Sitra fish trap locations present and proposes barge channel Sitra Pier to Sitra Anchorage', folded map (f. 197B);'Refinery Reservation to Sitra Terminal' (f. 222);'Parcel N. 5' (f. 230);'Reconnaissance map Doha Manifa to Maqta' hand coloured and sketched, with notes written by hand by Max Thornburg (f. 235).The volume also includes semestral 'Abstracts of accounts of oil measured' and 'Statement on Royalty' and monthly details on 'Shipments of oil from Bahrain' for 1937 and 1938. There are some newspaper cuttings, on the oil industry in the Gulf.There is an index at the end of the volume (folios 246-271).
